title: Align with Abundance: Rewrite Your Scarcity Story
summary: By a sunlit beach, a hopeful dreamer sheds her scarcity story and aligns with abundance vibration. Unexpected projects, effortless money flow, and inspired opportunities follow—proof that we really create our reality with the stories we tell.
principle: Your beliefs create your financial reality.
story:
Mara stepped off the minibus in Waigani Gardens, sunlight glinting on the glass towers of Port Moresby’s National Capital District. She glanced across Ela Beach Bay, her heart fluttering with ambition. For years she’d played small—convinced that financial freedom was reserved for someone else. Somewhere down the line, she’d accepted a scarcity story: there just wasn’t “enough” for her.

At a community mixer that evening, she met Jason, a broadcast engineer based at the local station near Convention Centre. His face lit up when she mentioned her dream of launching a bespoke arts publication. “I used to think I could only fix wires and set up transmitters,” he said, “but I shifted my beliefs about what my skills were worth, and suddenly projects—and paychecks—started flowing my way.”

Mara’s head buzzed. In her mind she replayed every time she’d doubted her own capacity. Yet listening to Jason’s story felt like a wake-up call. He described how he replaced his outdated inner script—“I’m not enough”—with “I attract abundance naturally.” Soon he upgraded his studio, invested in better gear, and landed international contracts.

The next morning, Mara walked into the open market where vendors sold saksak and laplap. She closed her eyes and breathed in the salty air. Replaying Jason’s words, she issued a silent affirmation: This publication is a success. Money flows to me effortlessly. She jotted down five reasons why she deserved it—quality content, local insight, passion for her community. The list felt surprisingly solid.

Week by week, Mara noticed subtle shifts. She felt lighter closing deals with printers in Boroko. She hesitated less when quoting rates to advertisers in Korobosea. Doors that once slammed in her face now opened. When she finally signed a three-month sponsorship agreement with a Port Moresby café chain, she barely recognized her own excitement.

Months later, when Mara and Jason shared dinner at Ela Beach Lodge, she raised her glass. “It wasn’t magic,” she said, smiling. “It was believing I was worthy of abundance.” Jason nodded. “We all create our reality with the stories we tell ourselves.” And under a canopy of stars, they celebrated how a shift in belief had transformed not just their bank balances, but their very lives.
